Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: toxic and non-toxic. Toxicity is defiend as anything that is rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable that would make someone want to leave a converation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: i am just sorry that khadr didnt get a bullet in the head before he blew the head off that innocent father because his islamic boogie skywizard told him to.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a toxic comment because it advocates acts of violence.
This is a non-toxic comment because it is not rude or desrespectful.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: "racism" -appears to be the only card in your deck!?
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be non-toxic because the comment only speaks of racism but does not disrespect any race.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Fat ass, go eat another do-nut.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be toxic because it disrespects the people that are overweight.

Comment: Dear Abby is missing the point when he says file it under 'her problems'. Fine advice if it was just the sister at risk. But having co-signed a mortgage, the mother must now maintain the house and the payments in order to avoid a default and a possible 'joint and several' claim against her and her hubby. 

Sadly there's no shortage of parents who have either refused to kick their offspring out of the nest or, worse still, put their own finances in jeopardy by helping them buy their own nest. Having not taught their daughter accountability and respect, she is unable to demand it of others. 

As to what advice to give, that would depend on whether the parents - even at this late stage - are prepared to grow a spine. If the mother is also half-owner of the house, she could insist on selling it off. It's more likely though that she owns nothing but the debt, in which case I would predict this will end badly for everyone - except of course the scum boyfriend.

Comment: I moved here in 2013...from Oceanside.  I was only in Oceanside for 2 years.  I was born an raised in Sonoma County for 45 years (18 of those on a small farm which became a shopping center).  My family (mother, grandparents, etc) are all from OR.  They left when my mom was 12 for better employment opportunities in CA.  They returned when I was 18.  I spent every summer in Prineville and Baker City.  I have one brother near Eugene and one near Olympia.  And yes, I also roll my eyes when I see California plates.  Only because I saw how the "haves" wreaked havoc on our housing prices there.  Now I see the same thing happening to Portland.  I don't want to live in a land of the "haves", entitlement, and excess....I left that land.  I want to live in a land of diversity, and compassion for the have-nots.

Comment: Most of the nine groups initially given status are tied to the legal profession; a few were religious in nature. None of the LGBT groups that applied were granted status. The perception clearly is that were not 'enough groups representing both sides'. 

Appeal courts have previously ruled that a key criteria for inclusion is the probative value of the input likely to be offered. Ostensibly Wagner took the view that the position of the LGBT community was already well documented in the submissions before it and, hence, that any additional argument was likely to be redundant. But the public doesn't always understand these nuances; and so as not to give rise to any apprehension of bias, it would have been wiser had some of LGBT groups been included. 

But two wrongs don't make a right. Better the court had issued the aforementioned explanation than to open itself to criticism that it could be swayed by whichever groups shouts the loudest. Its independence and integrity are paramount.

1) when you buy a COMPUTER, it has a CPU in it. Some are rated at say 2.0 ghz, and others at 3.0 ghz. These are the EXACT SAME CPU. This is true on YOUR PHONE. On any laptop, etc.  How do you obtain the faster speed? By changing the software. This is just 1 example of this.

Comment: Interesting time living out on the west coast. Day by day the radio reported fewer and fewer local commercial planes flying until even the twin turbo-props didn't fly. And waking up on Saturday morning in the middle of that spell, -46º in spite of the "warm" marine influence, and the village was silent. The recoil start on the snowmachine would barely return; one pull and then it very slowly crept back for another try. So while it was doing that, I pulled the plugs and brought them inside and heated them on the propane stove to help them along. When the engine finally came to life, I let 'er run the rest of the day in case some form of transport was needed in a hurry.

Comment: Really?

No question, the Chinese masterfully figure out how to copy and build cheaper. Rarely, if ever, better.

As for vested interests in fossil fuels, that is a complete red herring. In the US, fossil fuels are not revered, nor are they feared. Entrepreneurs like Elon Musk do not demand the neutering of Big Oil - he is convinced that he will beat them at their own game. In zero sum Canada, in order for one industry to prosper, another must be choked off by government.

The US understands that when a fuel source is found that beats oil and gas in terms of price, portability and energy density, then it is hasta la vista Big Oil. Until then however, all's fair.

Unlike in Canada where we persist in the fiction of thinking we are eco-laggards in  a world which is rapidly weaning itself off of oil, despite the fact of increasing, not decreasing global demand.

Our nanny state will see us getting poorer, with a few pats on the head from the eco-screamers to keep us warm.

Comment: The Globe article headline is "Doctors warn thousands could leave for U.S. over new federal tax hikes".  This is a misstatement.  There are no "new taxes"  for doctors. It appears some doctors have discovered a loophole to avoid the existing taxes by multiple use  of a small business rate.  The government is closing the loophole, so the doctors now have to pay what they should have done all along, in common with most other Canadians.

I find it unbelievable that many doctors would want to move to the USA because they were denied a loophole in their taxes.  This would imply that these doctors have no commitment to Canada or our way of life, and few if any family ties to keep them here.  Does the Globe really have evidence that many doctors would move, or is it just an imaginary claim in order to create more sensational articles?

Comment: The CDC reports that there are about 20 million cases of Norovirus in the U.S. every year, a large fraction of them from restaurants.  "Infected food workers are frequently the source of these outbreaks, often by touching ready-to-eat foods, such as raw fruits and vegetables, with their bare hands before serving them."  Using gloves is no panacea, true, but it will help.  What would help even more would be a requirement that food workers be given paid sick leave.  Food workers are generally poorly paid as it is, and it is a hardship for them to take off from work when they are ill, so they have a strong incentive to come to work even when ill.  Many outbreaks of Norovirus are traced to this kind of situation.

Comment: If two thirds of Canadians do indeed support climate change action (questionable), and if it is a question of how carbon pricing is implemented rather than if (again not fully convinced), then the best proposed plan so far is Michael Chong's national revenue neutral carbon tax.  

Chong's proposal is similar to the BC model, but it is initially revenue negative as large income and corporate tax cuts come first and the carbon price rises in a gradual predictable manner.  In turn a significant amount of government overhead on green funding programs is eliminated, so that markets are left to come up with solutions given the tax signals. 

Trudeau's approach layers carbon tax on top of existing green programs, and of course his additional intervention and spending.  Don't be fooled when he says revenue neutral, as 3 of 4 provinces (so far) have opted for a tax grab.

Chong is a long shot in the CPC race.  I'd rather have no carbon tax than a poorly designed one like the Trudeau 'plan'.

Comment: Hate to do this but this is 1 of 2.  Doing this for you John, not to fight with you but in case this can help a bit.  I know a bit about this because I helped my Mom die over 11 days at the shock trauma center (she was run over in a parking lot..and then the person not realizing what they had done..stopped and then backed over her again). 

First, you're not really rejecting my attitude of "if you are not totally serene"...because I never said that.  

What I said was that God wants His children to be totally serene, and He offers us many ways to approach this state of perfect union with Him, realizing that we are humans and will always be on an inclined plane toward that goal.

We will have moments of sorrow, short lapses of faith, and complaint.  And it's in those moments (but not just these moments) that God desires ever greater unity with us.

And He gives us ways to learn how to do this, and He's ready with grace in His hands to help us do this.

Comment: It's sad to read the many negative comments about teacher's salaries and benefits, especially considering 35 plus students per class. Unfortunately, it's not unusual, in all parts of the country.  I was in high school teaching for four years in California. Left as soon as I could, partly for the lack of support from local school board and community.  Fortunately, the National Science Foundation paid me to get my M.S. degree in Chemistry with all fees covered. I quickly moved on to an outstanding community college at one of the highest paying colleges in the country.  The respect from community, administration, and students was the difference between night and day.  

By having decent salaries and benefits, Eugene is able to attract the better teachers from all parts of the country.  Consider this (baby sitting wages): $10 an hour per student times 35 students equals $350 per class.  Five classes at $1750 a day times 190 days equals $332,500 per year.  $103,000 a year is a bargain!

Comment: Describing the City government's housing policies and goals as "weasel words" which the author does, hardly seems appropriate. Thats not because I think the Vision Council has done all they could to help with regard to controlling out of control speculation in the housing market, or providing sufficient social and rental housing. 

But to dismiss this out of hand is unfair.

 And lets remember, its not just the City government who has to be involved, but also senior levels of government. Which have been reluctant to help with social and cooperative and rental housing, and even if they talk favorably, its often more words than action. 

And we should never ever not give some of the credit for the diseaster that is home ownership and rental and social housing in Vancouver from real estate and development corporations, and ordinary citizens who saw dollar signs in their eyes when they discovered the home they bought in the 80s for $50,000 is can sell for a million.

Comment: The problem I have with your statement is this. You pretend as if Francis can just wave his wand and make the sex abuse problem go away. Fact of the matter is part of the reason why it's been hard to get prosecutions isn't because of the pope but because or stature of limitations laws in many countries.  

In 2015 for instance Francis cooperated with the law enforcement in Spain and sex abuse victims to charge on convict 11 priests of sex abuse. They got a conviction in January of 2015 but the Spanish court overruled the conviction citing statute of limitations.  

So it's a no win situation.  If he sets up the tribunal and deals with the problem internally like he proposed he's gonna be accuse or conflict of interest. If its take to the legal system there is a low chance of prosecution. 

So we shouldn't only be zeroing in on the church itself. The criminal justice system had to be scrutinized in how it deals with sex abuses cases legally.

Comment: This report really hits home for me. The real issue is that both young and old use their phone when they are driving or walking in public. These individuals believe that they can handle it. Reality hits when an accident occurs. Reality hit for me in 2008: my 11-year old was walking home from school - half-way through a crosswalk with the light still green and not on his phone - and he was hit by a large SUV that ran a red light. The driver was a mother who was on her phone and her kids were in the back seat. From police report, my son was thrown 140 feet. He survived. The woman's license was suspended in lieu of imprisonment. Almost 9 years later, my son is still piecing together his life. His little sister said it best: you can add up the medical bills and missing days from school, but you cannot bring back his fun-loving spirit; our family life was shattered. Is it worth it? Is it about your entitlement to your phone? Or is it more?

Comment: CO2 reflects sunlight and does indeed cool the planet.  However, the total amount of CO2 released by volcanoes averages about .26 gigatons per year, compared with 32 gigatons per year by human activity worldwide (US Energy Information Administration, for the year 2012).  Also, it is a major factor in ocean acidification.  The pH has fallen by .1 unit over the last few hundred years, which is about 30 percent more acidic.  By the end of this century, it will be nearly 150% more acidic, which will affect the entire food chain upon which about a billion people depend on for their livelihood and food (NOAA, et al).  Massive amounts of CO2 in the atmosphere is not our friend.

Comment: "...Ringo often was replaced on Beatles records."  Don't believe that is correct. Ringo was replaced ON DRUMS on one take of "Love Me Do"--instead,he plays Maracas.  The reason?  Starr was new to the group (1962), George Martin was nervous, so session drummer Andy White subbed.  The "White" version made the charts.  Years later, (after Ringo had stormed off in a snit, tired of waiting for the other three to show up at the studio) Paul played drums on "Back in the USSR."

Just two times, I believe, not "often."

"One good take out of hundreds"...if only it was that easy!  Often the "hit records" we remember so fondly are actually comprised of bits and pieces of two or three takes and the mixing takes longer than the performances.  Especially true of the Beach Boys later hits. Most people don't know, fewer really care.

Comment: Christian realism is a foreign policy perspective that originated with Reinhold Niebuhr, the famous moral theologian and public intellectual who was really a titanic figure on the American scene from the 1930s into the 1960s. The essence of Christian realism—which is very much at odds with anything that smacks of utopianism—is to appreciate that there is evil in the world to which we must respond but also to appreciate that our own motives are likely to be less pure than we may fancy them to be. It’s not simply that the motives of the other guys are suspect but we ourselves should always be mindful of the extent to which our own motives [may] be subject to question.
Andrew Bacevich

Comment: I am Jewish and can only speak to that.  The more liberal sects of Judaism (Reform and Reconstructionist) seem to be closer to what you are looking for.  Not there, but closer.  One of the things that both tend to push, especially in regards to some of the laws that look a little odd to modern people, is this idea of, if it is meaningful to you, then do it.  So do or don't keep kosher depending on how meaningful to you it is.  For some, that might mean just avoiding pork for others, it means not worrying about it at all.

The chosen people thing has always bugged me a bit, as well.  I do like the idea of tikkun olam (repairing the world).  I liken it to "the campsite rule", where you leave this world a little better than it was when you came into it.  This doesn't mean converting people, or doing good things to buy a golden ticket to heaven, it means doing good, to make the world today a better place, that might mean charity or helping at Habitat, or something else.

Comment: There are several problems with "natural law". There are multiple definitions of the term. One is "the law written in human hearts" (see Aquinas' Summa Theologica, I-II, q 94, art 6.) Another is "what is found in nature". (There is a third, having to do with legal theories.)

In practice, "natural law" can be misused in several ways:

It can mean nothing more than "this is what is written in my heart", which is the same as "in my opinion". Personal opinion is not a good basis for moral or dogmatic teachings.

It can be invoked when the person does not have an actual argument. A good example is in Humanae Vitae 4, which says essentially "we know the natural law, and you will just have to take our word for it". That's not an argument, that's blather.

When it does not actually describe how nature works. Humanae Vitae says that in nature, sexual intercourse is used for procreation. In fact, many of the great apes use it for pair bonding. So the author of HV got it wrong.

Comment: The thing about political polls is that they are, at best, an educated guess, and if you make enough guesses sooner or later some of them are going to be correct even if they seem like outliers.

Straight-up polling doesn't necessarily work for politics and election because it is subject to all kinds of systematic error.  Some of this shows up as sampling errors (ie the people who answer the phone call for your survey are not representative of the population as a whole) while other times it is simply a reporting bias (ie supporters of Marine Le Pen might be more likely than supports of Emmanuel Macron to say they are "undecided voters" because she is a controversial candidate).

The end result is that you can't apply standard statistics so any numbers are, at best, a guess.

What does that mean for France?  Who knows.  Mr. Marcron seems like the sensible choice to most but he, much like Hillary Clinton in the U.S., represents the status quo that so many are frustrated with.

Comment: Absolutely agreed.

Both assault and sexual assault see some common issues that work directly against getting convictions.  In both crimes, alcohol is involved in a gross majority of the cases, undermining the quality of testimony, substantially. In both crimes, the vast majority produce no corroborating physical evidence because there's no injuries. 98% of all sexual assaults reported last year had no injuries (type 1), for example. In addition, there's 3rd party witnesses in only a small fraction of the cases for both crimes.  There's generally slightly better chances for witnesses and visible injuries with assault, so the conviction rate is slightly higher, on average, but neither crime sees greater than half of the court cases get a guilty verdict.

Comment: Single-payer healthcare in California? The annual cost was: $400 billion. Of that, $200 billion would come from existing federal, state and local funding for healthcare. The remaining $200 billion would have to be raised from higher taxes. The plan of universal healthcare activists is to convince President Trump and the Republican-controlled Congress to transfer all the Medi-Cal billions to help leftist California finance a single-payer system, something they’d fear and deride as socialized medicine. The committee analysis assumed a 15% payroll tax on income. This in a state that already suffers from the highest income tax rates in the nation. But if all this happened, there’d still be between $50 billion and $100 billion in new money needed to fund a single-payer healthcare system. There’d be no premiums, co-pays or deductibles — and therefore no self controls. So who knows how steep new medical costs would climb?

By George SkeltonContact Reporter
Capitol Journal California

Comment: Several years ago, when using a computer with backup UPS power, the gauge
on the unit said the local utility (Chugach) was supplying 132 Volts... 

Since my 'uninterruptable power supply' with automatic voltage regulation on thoroughput was handling the irregularity with ease, I thought to call the dispatch line at Chugach; to inform them directly.

To be able to call the actual power experts, saves a lot of time and grief. I was able to
suggest that perhaps at an earlier maintenance interval, someone may have tested the system and had not set it back to the usual & customary output. I was spot-on; my suspicions confirmed.

(Not the first time I'd found an issue, or diagnosed a problem, as end-user Chugach customer.)

Most the people working there at desks have no idea what I've said, in regard to odd power effects, from a distance outside the city. They live a different life; many more outages, reasons, longer failures due to weather, trees, avalanches, etc. outside town. Such fun ;)

Comment: This claim should have gone nowhere. Church marriage law presumes that a married couple will have intercourse unless proven otherwise. Then, the burden of proof was on Catherine, and the operative word is "proof". Catherine's unsupported word should not have sufficed, and at the time she made this claim, she was not a virgin. Thus, she had no support whatsoever for her claim. Church marriage law holds that dubious claims about the validity of the marriage are to be dismissed in favor of the validity.

However, her other point of attack depended on her nephew Charles -- King of Spain, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Naples -- to oppose the annulment. Charles disliked Henry both personally and politically, and was happy to help his aunt. 

More importantly, in 1527, Naples and the Papal States had a war, which the Pope lost. Pope Clement VII did not want a re-run of that war, so he stalled by taking Catherine's claim seriously. There were special commissions and so on to waste time.

Comment: Here's a strategy that worked very well for us and allowed us to be mortgage free many years ago and saved us a ton of money.  The variable rate is generally always lower than the fixed rate. We consistently stayed on the variable rate but made payments equal to the fixed rate. When interest rates went up we stayed on the variable, got the new payment amount for the new fixed rate and adjusted our payments to that new fixed rate. In other words, we consistently overpaid our variable payments as if we were on a fixed rate mortgage, which we would of had to have paid should we have chosen to go on a fixed rate anyways. By taking advantage of the rate savings gap between the variable and fixed, together with the topped up payments (which we paid weekly by the way), the interest savings and drop in amortization was really quite astounding.

Comment: Scott:  You mention "current" abuse.  Would you be good enough to expand on your contention.  I presume you're referencing a possible initiative which might lead to a further initiativve to control aerial spraying of herbicides.  If, indeed, that is your concern, fine, you should be addressing that particular issue, not supporting an "end run" effort which would give the Board veto power over all initiatives which Lane County voters have worked hard to, and have in fact, qualified for the ballot.  May I again state: The initiative process comes with "built-in" checks to "weed out" frivolous measures.  First, it requires a significant number of petition signatures to qualify for the ballot.  Secondly, it requires a majority of voters to support its adoption. Thirdly, it,like all ordinances, would be subject to judicial review.  At each step proponents must make a convincing argument that the measure is a) constitutional and b) desirable.  This process is called DEMOCRACY.

There is a real "hole" in the system that does back ground checks for OCS and other agencies (private) that rely on it.
If a person has lost their "professional" license to be a mental health social worker or counselor because they had a sexual relationship with one of their juvenile clients in another state (Washington for example) but for some reason was never criminally charged, that person can move to Alaska and go to work at a agency that requires background checks and that person will pass. Comment: While I firmly believe that the community has a moral obligation treat the homeless with compassion and help them move into permanent housing, I also believe the homeless have a corresponding responsibility to the community at large.  They should not engage in activities which deprive the public of enjoyment of our public spaces and they should not endanger our biggest industry.  If homelessness were to have a serious impact on tourism it would threaten the jobs of many people who themselves are only a few paychecks away from being homeless – and many of the homeless I have interviewed have said the same thing themselves.  I believe it is one reason that most of the homeless in Waikiki are not locals – and yet, in response to Crystal’s point- it is an urban myth that the majority of our homeless come here from the mainland.  Close to 90% of the homeless had a residence in Hawaii before they became homeless.  (Apologies for the verbosity!)

Comment: The key to having no stress over tipping is to select the country well. There are many places where tipping is frowned upon or just not the thing. Vacation in these places and the money you save from not having to tip all the time more than makes up for the higher initial cost. When you visit the developing world, remember you are taking on the risk of being there (terrorism, disease, crime) and there is always somebody making a big profit from your presence (resort owner, hotel owner etc.). Don't plague yourself with guilt about tips: if the elite choose to leave their people poor, that is not your problem. 

It is a Canadian arrogance to think you will right the world's wrongs by generously tipping. 

Other options include staying in self-catering places, renting condos, camping, using a camper van etc. 

Buy a recipe book before hand and in many places you could cook a better meal than any restaurant would!

Comment: Here's an irony: Many believe keeping interest rates low will make homes more affordable when the opposite is true--Fed interest rates that are set too low for too long will have a tremendous impact on the creation of housing bubbles which have led to an unprecedented increase in housing prices across the U.S. starting in 1997. Thus it could be argued that the Fed would do better to adhere closely to the Taylor rule in their setting of the nominal interest rate. While we can't say for sure if we're in a housing bubble, one way to gauge the real value of housing is to compare it with long-term inflation. U.S. median family home prices are currently overvalued at around 30% above the long-term inflationary trend. This coupled with the fed funds rate near the 1% low which former Fed chairman Allan Greenspan set it, which triggered the housing bubble of 2005, could very well mean we're in the thick of another housing bubble. Do I hear trillion dollar government bailout of the big banks?

Comment: You want proof? I switched to being a private investor this year. Started selling my funds at the end of January: put more than 1/2 the money in high interest savings and term deposits and invested the rest in equities, starting in May. I had absolutely no experience when I started. Just did a whole lot of reading and talked to people who've been investing for years. Invested mainly in blue chips. For fun, I check the performance of my old funds on a daily basis. Here's where things stand today, 4 months after taking the plunge: 1) my old TFSA fund, 1.33% YTD; my new TFSA, 6.51%; 2) my old RRSP fund, 0.76 % YTD; I have two new RRSPs: one in a savings account at @ 2.10%, the other invested in the market is at 3.21%: the plan is to invest more in equities as I gain more experience; 3) my old RRIF fund is at minus 0.30% YTD; my new RRIF is earning 2.40%. So, in four months, and with no experience, my investments are doing better than with an advisor. Draw your own conclusions...

One more note.  On the positive side.   Kaczynski is trying to find a place where a line can be drawn, some way to put some definitions around what is and is not permissible.  I just do not know if it can be done by limiting decisions couples need to make regarding a child who is “very deformed” – I think that is a parental decision.  But, we need to put some definitions around abortion; it  should not be a normal form of birth control.  Most European countries put some limits on when an abortion is no longer a choice – most at 12, some 16 weeks, up to 20 weeks – I am open to correction.  In the U.S. we have been drawing these lines in state legislatures and finding some acceptance of restrictions starting at (I think) 20 weeks.  We need to deal with abortions afterward that protect the life of a woman and abortions in case of fetal abnormality.  We need to think about how to make some sense of BOTH the rights of child and the rights of a woman.  The Hyde Amndmnt needs to go.

Comment: Your comment reveals you know just enough about public school funding to pretend you actually understand it. No Child Left Behind (2001) conditioned federal education funds on standardized testing focused initiatives and scores. Feds put in about 12-15% of HIDOE's $2 billion+ annual budget, not the majority by far, but $250 million you can't afford to lose. The standardized testing requirements, incentivized (basically forced) districts to mostly drop art, music, PE, even social studies and science at first, to fund "test score chasing." This was contrary to what the research suggests is most effective, but money talks. Ku's right about Obama not doing much to fix it; in fact Race to the Top (2009) probably accelerated the trend in Hawaii. ESSA (2015) provides somewhat more flexibility, but only taking effect now. Otherwise, Ku is a kook on this subject, too. He'd do better to go home and kook rice.

Comment: Well, Rolling Stone is an odd choice of an authority about anonymous sources: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/05/business/media/rolling-stone-rape-story-case-guilty.html?_r=0 ... When The Washington Post uses an anonymous source, like it did in Watergate (http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/watergate/), the publication is on the line for its veracity. The Washington Post has created a lot of credibility for its work over at least the past 40 years, and it has not chosen to use those types of sources lightly (although one could argue that it has become less discerning in recent years, due to increased competition). Regardless, WaPo follows very strict protocols for anonymous sources, and it is accountable for that process (SPJ Code). ... As I have argued before, if someone recirculates a story, it also owns it. So, in this case, as you say, USA Today, NPR and WaPo (and others) all think this is credible information. So why, again, shouldn't we think it has validity? ...

Comment: Much of Canada's "top talent" moves to California which also has high taxation and a cost of living worst than Ontario!

It's really about career growth and job density...

Career growth: Many Fortune 500 corporations have satellite offices in Canada, but whether you're a manager or an engineer, you'll hit a glass ceiling. You have to work in their head offices to climb the corporate ladder or work on their core projects.

Job density: In Silicon Valley specifically, there are so many major corporations in close proximity, if one lays you off, you can move to their competitor down the street. In Canada, our tech industry is more spread out, so switching jobs often means uprooting your family and moving to another city.

Comment: When the facts demonstrate that the government is, in fact, trying to take our firearms, it isn't paranoia.

In 1967, the city of New York passed a law that required all rifles and shotguns to be registered.  Subsequently, in 1991, the city also banned semi-automatic rifles and using the registry already in their possession they issued notifications to those owners that their firearms must be removed from the city, disabled, or turned over to the authorities (ie: confiscation).  In 2013, they sent another round of letters demanding more removals or confiscations.

Also in 2013, Connecticut passed legislation that required gun owners to register their firearms and magazines.  Although few actually complied, in 2014 the State started low volume confiscation of those items registered by the people who complied with the legislation.

These are just a few examples, and there are even more in other countries, Australia and the UK to name a few.

Comment: The dams are not being overtopped at this point.  They're releasing a controlled amount through the gates and an additional amount is now going over the spillways.  Each dam has concrete-covered spillways located at the high ends of the basins that are several feet below the top of the earthen portion.  So far, Barker and Addicks are doing what they're designed to do.  That having been said, neither has ever held the amount of water currently behind the dams and the pressure behind them undoubtedly concerns authorities.  Agree that actual overtopping or failure of either one would do untold additional damage from the west side of Houston through downtown.

God by definition cannot have a "change of heart," but clearly over the span of time the Bible was written, less so for the Quran (which is puzzling, given its many conflicting commands toward peace and Jihad), the people's understanding of their God changed. Comment: Cracked column basalt and a transition forest that goes from oak savannah to rain forest conifer to rain shadow pine to oak savannah to high desert.   The slides will be released by water freezing and expanding,  and then thawing,  and rain lubricating the now loosened rocks.   Freezing is one of the important factors.  And rain on frozen ground can be a flash flood event.

Dead,  burned trees,  rot at the mean annual winter  snow level,  be that one foot   or four or more.  You can actually accurately guess the mean annual winter snow level by the height of the stumps from  blowdown in a burn area.  The real danger over time will be snag toboggans rocketing towards the railroad and freeway.....or the back of your home.  

Salvage log or not (that area is mostly helicopter logging ground),  the dead trees will fall.  The issue is who gets to control the aftermath.  My life experience includes fire watch duties,  and when the afternoon humidity dropped,  trees fell.  Wet rot dried out.

Comment: Part 1
There are many reasons why the medieval development of the altar as wall with a tabernacle as its center piece was not fortuitous. 

The most important has to do with our conception of the Eucharist as PRIMARILY (1) sacred food and drink, or (2) an object of adoration. 

The essence of Eucharist in scripture is sacred food. Jesus confected the Eurcharist at the Last Supper at the dinner table, and commanded us to both eat and drink. For most of the first thousand years, our churches faithfully conveyed that original divine intent with an altar that was instantly recognizable as a dinner table, to which bread and wine were brought, and from with the body and blood of Christ was distributed as sacred food and drink in the form of bread and wine. The original scriptural word that was adopted for a church building was "ekklesia," which means "gathering" and which came to be understood as the "place of gathering." Its Jewish predecessor was the synagogue (essentially same meaning).

Comment: A firm justification for laws limiting the freedom of citizens is the protection of others who might be adversely affected.  In the case of alcohol, there is a potential danger of drunken driving and other acts committed under the influence.  Good laws do not limit individual freedom unless it significantly advances the safety or rights of the general population.  In the present instance, the purchase and use of cigarettes by the younger population does not significantly impact the safety or rights of the general population.  Therefore this restriction on freedom does not conform to good democratic practice.  The dangers of second hand smoke are addressed by other laws prohibiting smoking in various places.  This law represents only the limitation of individual freedom because of the opinions and preferences of others.  In a free society, limitations on freedom should be avoided except when absolutely necessary.

Comment: While opinion articles are not bound by the normal rigors of journalistic fact checking, one would hope that a piece written by the Editorial Board would at least have its facts straight.
Tax revenue from recreational consumer sales do not pay for OLCC operation and regulation of the marijuana program. That is covered under the registration fees that are paid by everyone who owns a recreational marijuana business.
Furthermore the breakdown of the tax revenue is misleading. From the OLCC website the tax revenue is divided as follows:
40 % to Common School Fund, 
20 % to Mental Health Alcoholism and Drug Services, 
15 % to State Police, 
10 % to Cities for enforcement of the measure, 
10 % to Counties for enforcement of the measure, 
5 % to Oregon Health Authority for alcohol and drug abuse prevention. 
The taxes go to law enforcement and questionable drug prevention programs.  It's an issue that must be addressed in the legislature.

Comment: There are many examples of technological disruptors who succeeded to push "old-line" incumbents out far faster than investors anticipated or the incumbents could adapt. Here are a few...
- In 2008, Blockbuster CEO Jim Keyes told the Motley Fool that Netflix "isn't even on the radar screen in terms of competition". Just 2 years later, Blockbuster filed for bankruptcy.
- In 2006, Palm CEO Ed Colligan said of the newly announce iPhone "They’re not going to just walk in." Just 2 years later, Palm stopped making PDAs.
- In 2011, Nintendo president Reggie Fils-Aime dismissed mobile games. Just 4 years later, mobile game revenue overtook console game revenue.
- In 1977, DEC founder Ken Olsen said "There is no reason anyone would want a computer in their home,". Just 4 years later, IBM introduced the PC. Once the 2nd largest computer company in the world, DEC is now a footnote.

Comment: The Sioux, including Sitting Bull and Red Cloud accepted the terms of the Treaty of 1868 which placed the northern boundary at the 46th parallel and the Missouri River. Well south of the area of the pipeline. In 1873 an executive order was enacted that moved the border north to the Cannon Ball River, again well south of the pipeline location. The Sioux have accepted the treaty terms for that last 148 years. I would say that kind of trumps your argument, (pun intended). The treaty ;problems are with the Treaty of 1877 that was done without the consent of the Sioux as required by the Treaty  of 1868. It also broke up the one big reservation into several smaller reservations and took away the Black Hills, but the Sioux, rightfully, have never accepted the Treaty of 1877. I think they never should accept the Treaty of 1877. However, in every case, the northern boundary is the Cannon Ball River, still well south of the pipeline due to an executive order in 1873 moving the boundary north.
